The next recorded benefactor was John of Kilmarnock, burgess of Ayr, who in 1348 made large grants to the Black Friars, making over to them for the weal of his soul, and the souls of his parents, and of all faithful successors, for light to be burned on the high altar, and for the repair of the house of S. Katherine the Virgin, and for 1116 own sustenance during life in the same place, all his lands and annualrents ,111 the territory of the burgh of Ayr, or outside of it.3 The list of these4 is highly interesting, as showing the property of a wealthy burgess at the time.

Besides the usual confirmation, Robert IL, by letters patent, took the Friars Preachers of Ayr under his sure fence and protection.5
